awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Robotized Plasmonic Nanosensors for High-Throughput Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: 

EAGER: Robotized Plasmonic Nanosensors for High-Throughput Biochemical Detection 

Goal: 

The goal of the proposal is to explore an innovative paradigm for robotizing Plasmonic Nanosensors for high-throughput detection of ultralow-concentration molecules.

Nontechnical Abstract:
Nanosensors with ultra-sensitivity and high throughput are pivotal for early-stage disease diagnosis. Significant efforts have advanced nanosensors with single-molecule sensitivity owing to the unique physical properties of nanoscale materials. However, the high sensitivity of nanosensors comes at the expense of an adversely long detection time for low-concentration biomolecules. It is due to the low probability of dilute molecules to attach to nano-sized objects. Therefore, both the effects of the high-sensitivity and low-detection speed result from the miniaturized dimensions of nanosensors. This pressing issue has greatly hindered the practical application of nano-biosensors. In this work, the PI proposes to explore an innovative concept of robotized plasmonic nanosensors for enhancing the detection throughput via active mechanical rotation while retaining the high sensitivity. If successful, this work can accelerate the reality of point-of-care diagnosis and early cancer detection that improve people's healthcare. It will also benefit our next-generation from undergraduate to graduate levels with special promotions to the underrepresented female students in engineering. Organization of a symposium at the Materials Research Society Meeting by the PI will gather leading researchers from both academia and industry in this fast developing field for accelerating technological discovery and transfer. 

Technical Abstract:
The objective of this research is to explore an innovative paradigm for robotizing plasmonic nanosensors for high-throughput detection of ultralow-concentration molecules. Significant efforts have advanced nanoscale sensors with single-molecule sensitivity. However, the nanoscale features of sensors, which enable ultrasensitive detection, also result in a low detection speed due to the intrinsic low-attachment probability of molecules to the small available sensing areas. The difficulties are compounded further by the complex fabrication and integration of the nanosensors to existing systems, such as microfluidics, for practical applications. In this proof-of-concept project, an attempt will be made to robotize plasmonic nanosensors into highly controllable nanomotors to address the aforementioned challenges. The sensors will be assembled and actuated into motorized sensors by utilizing the electric tweezers an efficient nanomanipulation technique, based on the combined AC and DC electric fields, developed by the PI recently. The greatly enhanced detection speed for ultralow-concentration molecules is expected owing to the effective fluidic convection as a result of the controlled mechanical rotation of the nanosensors, which could accelerate the affiliation equilibrium of analyte molecules with the surfaces of nanosensors. Since no such kind of systems has been investigated previously and the mechanisms have not been tested or proved, this proposal will present high risk, while potentially transformative. 

If successful, the proposed research will innovatively integrate and actuate plasmonic-active nanoparticles into functional nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) devices for enhanced biochemical detection, representing a new advance of optical nanosensors from a passive/static fashion to a dynamic/actuatable fashion. The concept and advantages of the robotized optical sensors, if approved, should be applicable and transformative to all types of nanosensors.

por.por_cntn:
In this research, we proposed to test an innovative scheme of robotic nanomotor sensors for ultrasensitive biochemical detection by using Raman spectroscopy. We hypothesized that if we could mechanically rotate the nanosensors controllably, i.e. motorizing nanosensors, the resulted fluidic convection and mixing could significantly reduce and even essentially eliminate the molecular depletion region in the electric double layer. As a result, the time for molecules to transport and attach to the surfaces of nanosensors can be substantially reduced, which makes the high-throughput detection possible for even ultra-low concentration molecules.

     We realized what we proposed, successfully proved the hypothesis — motorized nanosensors can substantially reduce the detection time of molecules without compromise of the detection sensitivity.

     We achieved the results in four aspects. First, we investigated an innovative type of photonic-plasmonic hybrid Raman nanosensors integrated with electrokinetic manipulation by rational design, which offers dual mechanisms that enhance the sensitivity for molecule detection directly in solution. For the first time, we integrate large arrays of synthesized plasmonic nanocapsules with densely surface distributed silver (Ag) nanoparticles (NPs) on lithographically patterned photonic crystals via electric-field assembling. With the microelectrodes, the applied electric fields not only assemble the hybrid plasmonic nanocapsules on photonic crystals but also generate electrokinetic flows that focus analyte molecules to the Ag hot spots on the nanocapsules for Surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) detection. The synergistic effects of plasmonic-photonic resonance and the electrokinetic molecular focusing can promote the SERS enhancement factor (EF) robustly to ~2×109. Various molecules including SERS probing molecules, nucleobases, and unsafe food additives can be detected directly from suspension. The innovative mechanism, design, and fabrication reported in this work can inspire a new paradigm for achieving high-performance Raman nanosensors, which is pivotal for lab-on-chip disease diagnosis and environmental protection.

      With the above understanding, we exploited the synthesis of plasmonic Ag nanoparticles on diatom frustules that have naturally existing ordered arrays of nanoholes, forming into photonic crystals. Indeed, with laser illumination, the electric-field intensity at the junctions of Ag nanoparticles is improved by approximately two times. The results have been confirmed by both numerical simulation and experimental studies. 

    Next, we investigated rotary bio-micromachines by using diatom frustules as integrated active components, including the assembling, operation, and performance characterization. We further studied and demonstrated unique applications of the bio-micromachines in achieving individually reconfigurable micromachine arrays and microfluidic mixing. Diatom frustules are porous cell walls of diatoms made of silica. We assembled rotary micromachines consisting of diatom frustules serving as rotors and patterned magnets serving as bearings in electric fields. Ordered arrays of micromotors can be integrated and rotated with controlled orientation and speed up to ~3000 rpm, one of the highest in biomaterial-based rotary micromachines. Moreover, by exploiting the distinct electro-mechanical properties of diatom frustules and metallic nanowires, we realized the first reconfigurable rotary micro/nanomachine arrays with controllability in individual motors. Finally, the diatom micromachines were successfully integrated in microfluidic channels and operated as mixers.

     With the results obtained as above, we fabricated and characterized plasmonic-active nanosensors made of diatom frustules coated with dense arrays of Ag nanoparticles and thin layers of Ni film, which can readily detect molecules with the sSERS technique and rotate with controlled speed and chirality in electromagnetic fields. Next, we rotate the plasmonic-active nanosensors with a magnetic field up to ~1200 rpm in strategically fabricated microfluidic wells. Then, we used SERS to detect the real-time capture of DNA molecules by the plasmonic-active nanosensors during mechanical rotation and analyzed the dependence of absorption rate of DNA molecules on the rotation speed. Impressively, we can increase the molecule capture efficiency by 3 times at a rotation speed of just 700 rpm, i.e. reducing the saturation time from 17 min to 5-6 min. The DNA absorption rate monotonically increases with the rotation speed of the diatom microsensors with a power law dependence of ~0.49. We further studied the effect of rotation speed on detection speed of low concentration DNA molecules. We found that with rotation of the plasmonic sensors, SERS signals of molecules appear in a much shorter time (3 min) compared to those on non-rotating nanosensors (10 min). 

This work proved the success of an innovative concept of motorized nanosensors for ultrasensitive and high-throughput detection. The result is transformative to all types of nanosensors, which could inspire a new class of reconfigurable photonic/plasmonic NEMS devices.

 The new knowledge and understanding contribute to both fundamental sciences and engineering fields of NEMS, optics, biochemical sensing, and lab-on-chip. It could accelerate the reality of point-of-care diagnosis and early cancer detection that impact people’s healthcare. It benefits our next-generation from undergraduate to graduate levels. A Materials Research Meeting (MRS) symposium is organized for efficient communication in this fast advancing field.
